sources.data_found: Hoffman2 Cluster Hardware Specification: Lists node types including 'gpu' (general), 'g1-a100', 'g4-a100', 'g1-v100', 'g4-v100', and A40 nodes. Confirms presence of NVIDIA A100 (40GB/80GB), V100, and A40 GPUs.
Hoffman2 GPU Access documentation: Describes CUDA queues. Lists available GPU generations: A100, V100, A40, RTX 2080 Ti. Mentions nodes with 4x GPUs (e.g., g4 queues) and single GPU nodes.
UCLA Academic Planning and Budget - Enrollment by Major (Fall 2023): Computer Science (BS) 1,467; Computer Science and Engineering (BS) 332; Computer Science (MS/PhD) graduate totals.

student_data.notes: Data sourced from UCLA Academic Planning and Budget (Fall 2023 Enrollment). Undergrad count includes 'Computer Science' (1,467) and 'Computer Science and Engineering' (332). Grad MS count (482) and PhD count (315) derived from Engineering graduate enrollment tables for Computer Science.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: Available in the 'gpu' queue for non-ECC workloads; estimated count based on legacy node availability.
Mentioned in teaching cluster documentation (limited availability).

gpu_resources.notes: UCLA Hoffman2 is a 'condo' model cluster, meaning precise real-time counts fluctuate as researchers purchase nodes. Counts are estimated baselines from IDRE hardware documentation and OARC capacity statements ('over 500 GPUs'). Breakdown logic: A100s (mix of g4-a100 80GB and g1-a100) estimated at ~124 total. V100s (legacy workhorse) estimated at ~160. A40s (visualization/AI) estimated at ~32. RTX/Consumer cards make up the remainder of the 500+ total. H100s not yet listed in public hardware queues.

analysis_notes: UCLA does not publish a live dashboard like Stanford's Sherlock. GPU counts are derived from the Hoffman2 hardware node types (g1-a100, g4-v100, etc.) and capacity statements in OARC presentations.
